The **World Rugby Under 20 Championship** (known as the **IRB Junior World
Championship** until 2014) is an international [rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union
"Rugby union") competition. The event is organised by the sport's governing
body, [World Rugby](/wiki/World_Rugby "World Rugby"), and is contested by 12
men's junior national teams with an under-20 age requirement. This event
replaced the IRB's former age-grade world championships, the [Under
19](/wiki/Under_19_Rugby_World_Championship "Under 19 Rugby World
Championship") and [Under 21](/wiki/Under_21_Rugby_World_Championship "Under
21 Rugby World Championship") World Championships.

The inaugural tournament was held in June 2008, hosted by [Wales](/wiki/Wales
"Wales") and with 16 teams participating. Wales was announced as host for the
inaugural tournament in November 2007.[1] The number of participating nations
was reduced to 12 before the 2010 tournament due to financial reasons.[2]

The U20 Championship is the upper level of the World Rugby tournament
structure for under-20 national sides. At the same time that the U20
Championship was launched, World Rugby (then known as the International Rugby
Board) also launched a second-level competition, the [U20
Trophy](/wiki/World_Rugby_Under_20_Trophy "World Rugby Under 20 Trophy"),
featuring eight teams.

Promotion and relegation between the Trophy and the Championship is in place.
The winner of the Trophy will play in next year's Championship, while the last
placed team at the Championship will be relegated to the Trophy for the next
year.
